moves.1. d4: Really started to look at a queens pawn opening after got stuck in a rut with the whole kings pawn/spanish game
moves.1... e6 2. Nf3 d5 3. Bf4 Bd6: development as normal, debated here what to do about the trade with the dark squared bishops, did consider Ne5 for a while to stall it and offer a good attacking option on F7 pawn. but....
moves.4. Bg3: in the end decided on Bg3
moves.5. hxg3: White is more than happy as this frees up the H file for some future attacking options. Although does mean that a kings side castle is out of the question so white must be clean & quick!!
moves.5... Nf6 6. e3 O-O: ! This could prove to be costly as white has a powerful attack on the H7 pawn
moves.7. Bd3: White continues to attack and mount pressure on the .... H7 pawn
moves.7... b6 8. Nbd2 c5: a pawn exchange is offered to weaken whites hold in the center
moves.9. c3: White supports the d4 pawn - if c5xd4 then white would follow ith e5xd4 keeping the  queen side strong and have a semi free file on the E's for more queen action!! but...
moves.9... c4: black advances his pawns into the whites half of the board applying pressure on the light squared bishop
moves.11... Nxe5 12. dxe5: White trades Knights but in the process kicks the defending knight from his perch
moves.12... Ng4: Although appears to be obvious mistake i dont think it had an overbearing affect on the outcome?!?
moves.13. Qxg4: Black is under massive pressure and totally penned in
moves.13... h6: a last ditch attempt to stop the invading bishop
moves.14. Rxh6: nothing the g7 pawn can do as the white queen holds the G file
moves.14... g6: by this time its all really over but
moves.15. Rxg6+: white sacs his rook with Qxg6, Kh8, Qh7=m8 . I would like to thank Milatin for the game. and hope my attempt at annotating a game hasn't  been to bad!
